results.title: Le Petit Soldat = the Little Soldier
results.creator_credit: Georges de Beauregard and Jean-Luc Godard
results.brief_description:
In Geneva, at the time of the Algerian War, a French secret agent, on a mission to kill a top man in the FLN, finds himself used as a pawn by both sides. Filmed in 1960, Godard’s second feature film was banned by the French government and released, with minor cuts, in 1963 because of its ambivalent attitude to the Algerian War and its reflection of brutality on both sides. Other reasons might have been its matter of fact filming of torture and the treatment of the political crisis as a confusing gangster movie.

Credits: Producer, Georges de beauregard ; director, Jean-Luc Godard ; writer, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard ; music, Maurice Le Roux.
Cast: Michel Subor, Anna Karina, Henri-Jacques Huet, Laszlo Szabo, Mohamed Messoussa.

results.title: Le Petit Soldat
results.brief_description:
The peaceful life of the residents of a toy shop is disturbed by a goverment order declaring war on all toys and ordering their destruction. A mechanical acrobat, in love with a wax doll, must become a toy soldier in order to restore peace in the shop. While he is away, the wax doll falls prey to a nasty toy bird.

Credits: Producer, Andre Sarut ; director, Paul Grimault ; writers, Paul Grimault, Jacques Prevert ; music, Joseph Kosma.

results.title: Le Petit Parisien = the Little Parisian
results.brief_description:
Episode 1 of Series “Lagardere”.
Philippe de Gonzague has vowed to become the master of the richest estate in France. To achieve this, he has to destroy the lives of all those standing in his way. His first victim will be his friend Philippe de Nevers, his wife Blanche de Caylus and their young daughter, Aurore, who stands to inherit the estate. Gonzague sends two fencing masters, Staupitz and Cocardasse to eliminate Nevers, meanwhile, Henri (aka the little Parisian) who works as an acrobat in a travelling circus is told by his nanny the secret of his origins. As Henri comes out to stake his claim on his estate, he finds himself embroiled in Gonzague’s web of intrigue, murder and kidnapping. This popular story hs been adapted to the screen many times. See also in our collection: ‘The hunchback’ (X000159).

Credits: Producer, Robert Velin ; director, Jean-Pierre Decourt ; writers, Marcel Jullian, Jean-Pierre Decourt ; photography, Georges Barsky ; music, Jacques Loussier.
Cast: Jean Piat, Jacques Dufilho, Jean-Pierre Darras, Nadine Alari, Jacques Balutin, Claude Confortes, Marco Perrin.

results.title: Le Petit Marcel = Little Marcel
results.brief_description:
After he inherits his father’s truck, Marcel makes the big trip to Paris in the hope of setting up a transport business. While awaiting the his truck rego, he becomes involved with a gang of people under police surveillance.

Credits: Director, Jacques Fansten ; writers, Jean-Claude Grumberg, Jacques Fansten ; photography, Jean Gonnet ; music, Graeme Allwright.
Cast: Jacques Spiesser, Isabelle Huppert, Yves Robert, Jean-Francois Balmer, Michel Aumont, Anouk Ferjak ; Hubert Gignoux.
results.description:

results.title: Le Pelican = the Pelican
results.brief_description:
Paul, a jazz musician, lives with his wife, Isabelle and their young boy, Marc. He is offered to tour the USA for what he thinks is a vast amount of money. Instead, he spends ten years in prison for passing counterfeit money. On his return to France, he is informed he has lost custody of his child. Considering he has been victimized enough by his sojourn in prison, Paul decides to go in search of Marc. At first, he is happy enough to observe the boy from a distance, but after a while, he realises his need for close contact and puts a plan together to kidnap his son.

Credits: Director, Gerard Blain ; writers, Gerard Blain, Andre de Baeque, Marie-Helene Bauret ; photography, Daniel Gaudry ; music, Jean-Pierre Sabar.
Cast: Gerard Blain, Dominique Ravix, Daniel Sarky, Cesar Chauveau.

results.title: Le Passager de la Pluie = Passengers of the Rain
results.brief_description:
Melie kills the stalker who assaulted and raped her and then disposes of the body. When the body is recovered, Dobbs, an American military officer accuses Melie of the murder and of stealing the US Army money that the rapist had been carrying with him. Awards: Golden Globe 1971 for Best Foreign Film.

Credits: Producer, Serge Silberman ; director, Rene Clement ; writers, Sebastien Japrisot, Lorenzo Ventavoli ; photography, Andreas Winding ; music, Francis Lai.
Cast: Marlene Jobert, Charles Bronson, Annie Cordy, Jean Gaven, Gabriele Tinti, Jean Piat, Jill Ireland, Corrine Marchand.

results.title: Le Passage du Rhin = Tomorrow Is My Turn
results.brief_description:
Roger, a baker, and Jean, a journalist, are both interned in a POW camp in Germany. They are given an opportuniy to escape when they are taken to work as farm hands on local properties. Jean tricks the farmer’s innocent daughter, Helga, into helping him escape. Roger, who has truly fallen for a local girl, decides to stay. But, soon after Jean’s escape, Helga falls under the suspicion of the local authorities. Award: Venice Film Festival 1960: Golden Lion.

Credits: Director, Andre Cayatte ; writers, Andre Cayatte, Armand Jammot, Maurice Auberge, Pascal Jardin ; photography, Roger Fellous ; music, Louiguy.
Cast: Nicole Courcel, Charles Aznavour, Cordula Trantow, Georges Riviere, Betty Schneider, Georges Chamarat, Colette Regis, Alfred Schieske, Ruth Hansmeister, Jean Marchat.

results.title: Le Paris de Robert Doisneau
results.brief_description:
Robert Doisneau’s unique vision of Paris is presented through a montage of his most famous photographs. There is no commentary, only music and sound effects.

Credits: Producer, Marie Corajoud ; director, Francois Porcile ; photography, Pierre Dupouey ; music, Pierre Gamet.

results.title: Le Pactole = the Loot
results.brief_description:
A young couple pulls off a bank robbery only to be blackmailed by a witness, who turns out to be a corrupt police officer.

Credits: Producer, Roger Fleytoux ; director, Jean-Pierre Mocky ; writers, Patrick Granier, Jean-Pierre Mocky ; photography, Edmond Richard ; music, Roger Loubet.
Cast: Richard Bohringer, Patrick Sebastien, Pauline Lafont, Marie Laforet, Bernadette Lafont.
